support_summary: Profilin 1 (PFN1) is a protein that directly interacts with TDP-43. ALS-associated mutations in PFN1 (e.g., C71G) cause it to form insoluble aggregates which sequester TDP-43, inducing its hyperphosphorylation and promoting the formation of prion-like, toxic TDP-43 inclusions.

functions.cellular_process: Mutant Profilin 1 (PFN1), specifically variants associated with ALS, forms cytoplasmic aggregates that sequester endogenous TDP-43. This interaction facilitates the conversion of soluble TDP-43 into a prion-like, insoluble, and hyperphosphorylated state, seeding further aggregation.
functions.effect_description: Mutant PFN1 acts as a seed to induce the aggregation and hyperphosphorylation of endogenous TDP-43, leading to the formation of toxic cytoplasmic inclusions.
biological_consequence: Expression of mutant PFN1 (e.g., C71G) → PFN1 forms cytoplasmic aggregates → Sequestration of endogenous TDP-43 → TDP-43 hyperphosphorylation & conversion to an insoluble, prion-like state → Seeding of further TDP-43 aggregation → Neurodegeneration
specific_effects: Transgenic expression of PFN1(C71G) in mice induces early and progressive hyperphosphorylation of endogenous TDP-43 in the spinal cord. [8]
TDP-43 pathology precedes the onset of muscle denervation and motor deficits in PFN1(C71G) mice. [8]
Mutant PFN1 aggregates sequester endogenous TDP-43 in the cytoplasm. [6, 7]
Insoluble fractions from cells with mutant PFN1 can seed TDP-43 aggregation in recipient cells. [5, 6]

evidence.paper_title: Viral-mediated knockdown of Atxn2 attenuates TDP-43 pathology and muscle dysfunction in the PFN1C71G ALS mouse model
evidence.authors: Hawley ZCE, Li X, Bodnar D, Gu Y, Luo Y, Ferretti D, Sheehy A, Driscoll R, Zavodszky MI, Cao S, Isaza I, Wang L, Petrucelli L, Zhang YJ
evidence.relevant_quote: We show that transgenic neuronal expression of PFN1(C71G) induces early hyperphosphorylation of endogenous TDP-43 in the spinal cord that augments over time, preceding accumulation of insoluble non-phosphorylated TDP-43...

evidence.paper_title: Profilin 1 mutants form aggregates that induce accumulation of prion-like TDP-43
evidence.authors: Tanaka Y, Nonaka T, Suzuki G, Kametani F, Hasegawa M
evidence.relevant_quote: Expression of PFN1 with pathogenic mutations resulted in the formation of cytoplasmic aggregates positive for p62 and ubiquitin, and these aggregates sequestered endogenous TDP-43. [6]

evidence.paper_title: Gain-of-function profilin 1 mutations linked to familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis cause seed-dependent intracellular TDP-43 aggregation
evidence.authors: Tanaka Y, Nonaka T, Suzuki G, Kametani F, Hasegawa M
evidence.assay: Cell culture, Western Blot, Seeding assay
evidence.relevant_quote: insoluble fractions prepared from cells expressing ALS-linked mutant PFN1 functioned as a seed to induce accumulation and phosphorylation of TDP-43, indicating that TDP-43...is converted to prion-like species. [7]

mechanism: Mutant Profilin 1 (PFN1), specifically variants associated with ALS, forms cytoplasmic aggregates that sequester endogenous TDP-43. This interaction facilitates the conversion of soluble TDP-43 into a prion-like, insoluble, and hyperphosphorylated state, seeding further aggregation.
effect: Mutant PFN1 acts as a seed to induce the aggregation and hyperphosphorylation of endogenous TDP-43, leading to the formation of toxic cytoplasmic inclusions.
summary: TDP43 activates PFN1 to modulate tdp-43 aggregation, ultimately affecting neurodegeneration.
